item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by Dinwar
item.description:
4: Infrastructure. Specifically:

1) Repair or replace bridges that are past their useful lifespan or have low rates on inspections. Think of it this way: One of the biggest military assets in any invasion is the bridges. By failing to maintain or replace these, we are essentially declaring war on ourselves and suffering some of the consequences of an enemy invasion merely through our own sloth. The warnings about bridge collapses are remarkably similar to the warnings about the New Orleans levies I heard prior to Katrina--experts shouting as loudly as they can "This will kill people!!" and everyone ignoring them because no one's died yet. As a bonus, this is a way to get bipartisan support--more efficient construction methods would decrease ecological impact and environmental costs, while also increasing blue-collar work for decades.

2) The electrical grid. We CANNOT transmit enough electricity to power the future; in some cases we can't even power today. An astonishing amount of our electrical grid is past its useful lifespan as well. The future will be more energy intensive. We should be building the infrastructure to handle this load now, rather than reactively building in response to disasters.

3) Mine asteroids. This is a bit pie-in-the-sky, but the rewards would be tremendous so I'd think it's worth trying. The elements we need to build existing technology, to say nothing of future technology, are considered rare-earth elements because they fell below the crust during the fractionation the Earth went through as it cooled. Asteroids did not undergo that process, and key elements that are rare on Earth are practically as common as iron in these asteroids. We know we can grab material and bring it back; we know we can manipulate asteroid orbital paths. Let's park one in orbit (around the Moon or at a LaGrange point, so it doesn't smack into our planet accidently) and mine the sucker.

item.title: Comment on Who was the wealthiest man in the world in the 1830s? by mkt42
item.description:
Chile peppers became big all over the world (lower latitudes anyway).

Potatoes were huge for Europe, but less so for China. I suppose they were fine with the rice and wheat they were already growing, whereas potatoes could produce unprecedented food yields for places such as Ireland. (I did observe that fried potatoes were a very popular street food in ChongQing. Not something that we normally associate with Sichuan cuisine -- but these fried potatoes had red chiles mixed in.)

Maize may've done something similar for sub-Saharan Africa, it seemed to be widespread not just in cities but in the hinterlands too:

"Maize accounts for 30−50% of low-income household expenditures in Africa. Over 30% of the caloric intake of people in sub‐Saharan Africa comes from maize."
https://www.iita.org/cropsnew/maize/

Chocolate/cocoa is more of a luxury product than a staple, it's also widespread but though it's certainly available in places such as Africa and China it's not as commonly seen as maize, potatoes, etc.

But though those New World foods revolutionized cuisine and nutrition worldwide, the continents that were really revolutionized were the Americas, where the Europeans brought beef, pork, wheat, onions, rice, bananas (from Africa, but via the colonizers), etc. etc. Interestingly the Incas had chickens -- that had to have been brought by Polynesians.

item.title: Comment on Economists’ predictions from 1980 by Faze
item.description:
Milton Friedman is among the many expert contributors to the 1981 book, The People’s Almanac Presents the Book of Predictions. The authors of this 500-page, small-type book queried experts ranging from Shere Hite, to Andrei Sakharov, Friedman, Arthur C. Clark, and so on, to collect a detailed catalogue of predilections for specific and less specific dates in the future. Everyone should try to get their hands on this book, and re-read it every five years or so, as I do. It’s a great corrective to the bad habit of couching our biases and opinion in the form of predictions. So many of these expert opinions are spectacularly wrong, and some are so startlingly right (up to a point), that it is also immensely entertaining. (Nobel-winner Friedman, by the way, is asked to predict future winners of the Nobel in Economics. His guesses in 1981 were George Stiegler, Gary Becker, Martin Feldstein, Robert Lucas and Franco Modigliani. That’s two correct, if I’m not mistaken.)
